title: The $100 Billion Breakthrough: How AI is Finally Solving the Biggest Bottleneck in Drug Manufacturing
name: Yi Qu
summary: A quiet revolution is underway, driven by the surging demand for some of the most important new medicines today—specifically, peptides. These critical building blocks are the core components of modern therapeutics, including the rapidly growing GLP-1 treatments used for diabetes and weight loss. The numbers are staggering: the global peptide market is projected to more than double by 2030, potentially reaching over $100 billion. Yet, this massive growth faces an immediate, tangible threat: supply chain constraints and chemical processes that are difficult to scale up. This urgent need for innovation is why WR Grace & Co, a global leader in specialty chemicals, has struck a strategic, multi-year pact with Molecule.one, a pioneer in chemical AI. Their mission: to reinvent how these crucial chemical compounds are manufactured at scale and break the manufacturing bottlenecks slowing down innovation. MARIA: The Engine Driving Novel Chemistry The key to this collaboration is the deployment of Molecule.one’s MARIA AI and high-throughput experimentation platform. This platform is more than just a software tool; it combines computational intelligence with thousands of autonomously executed, miniaturized reactions. By doing this, MARIA rapidly identifies and prioritizes production routes that are far more efficient than conventional methods. The partnership is starting by advancing the synthesis of select peptide components, aiming to use this combined approach to deliver scalable solutions that outperform older peptide synthesis methods. As Brenda Kelly, President of Materials Technologies at Grace, noted, combining Grace’s deep expertise in fine chemicals with Molecule.one’s platform is intended to transform how they scale and manufacture pharmaceuticals, while also strengthening their capabilities at their US Fine Chemicals Manufacturing sites.

title: AI Digest — AI-Ready Chemistry Secures Drug Supply, Plus ChatGPT's Shopping Edge
name: Yi Qu
summary: The digest covers how AI-ready chemistry is securing the drug supply chain and the launch of ChatGPT's new personalized shopping feature. It also touches on Meta's content licensing deals and a positive outlook on AI's impact on job creation.

title: What I Learned About the Future of Work from Microsoft's Internal HR Transformation

title: How I Decide When to Split a Document for AI (and My Simple Rules)
excerpt: When I first used AI to search my notes, I dropped giant files into the system and hoped for magic. Instead, I got slow searches, vague answers, and sometimes the AI skipped the one section I needed. So I changed my approach. Now, before I upload anything, I pause and ask: Should I split this into smaller pieces, or keep it as one file?
name: Yi Qu

title: Today's AI Digest — Frontier Models, Drug Discovery, and Data Scarcity
name: Yi Qu
summary: This digest focuses on the release of frontier models like Mistral 3 and Gen-4.5, the validation of an AI-designed drug, and the critical issue of data scarcity forcing a shift to synthetic data.

name: Yi Qu
summary: This digest covers major developments in AI, including a $45M funding round for ChemLex's automated drug discovery lab, President Trump's plan for a single national AI regulatory framework, the partnership between Warby Parker and Google on AI-powered smart glasses, and the expansion of Google's Gemini 3 Pro to the command-line interface.

title: Why I Did It with the Mindset of “AI First” (and Why Verification Matters)
name: Yi Qu
summary: I got a request to complete a spreadsheet, but the information was scattered across many long reports. Instead of spending hours reading and copying, I approached it with the mindset of “AI first.”

title: From Hobbyist to Enterprise: Mastering Workflow Automation with Make
name: Yi Qu
summary: In a session led by Make, the focus was on moving beyond simple task automation to implementing enterprise-grade governance, lifecycle management, and reliable AI integration for workflows. The session provided a technical deep dive into event-driven architecture using Google Apps Script and Webhooks, and outlined a critical scenario lifecycle for managing automations.

title: A Simple AI Tip: Use Built-In OCR Instead of Installing Your Own
name: Yi Qu
summary: Many AI assistants now include powerful Optical Character Recognition (OCR) built-in. This tip suggests using the AI's native OCR capabilities to convert images or PDFs with text into editable text, bypassing the need for separate, often complex, local OCR software like Tesseract.

title: Turn a Paper Business Card into a Phone Contact with AI
name: Yi Qu
summary: A simple, three-step guide on how to use an AI chat app (like ChatGPT) to quickly convert a physical business card into a digital phone contact (vCard file), eliminating manual typing and reducing errors.

title: How I Turn Scanned PDF Tables into Excel
name: Yi Qu
summary: A guide on using AI to extract data from scanned PDF tables and convert it into an Excel-ready format, focusing on the efficiency and accuracy of modern AI tools over traditional OCR methods.

title: 5 Google Agent Playbooks You Should Read
name: Yi Qu
summary: A short guide to five free whitepapers from Google and Kaggle (over 250 pages) on building real-world AI agents, covering agent basics, tools (MCP), memory, quality, and production. It provides a quick summary of each paper's key takeaways.

title: Today's AI Digest — AI's Architects Take Center Stage, Plus a Scientific Leap

summary: Today's AI Digest covers Time magazine naming 'The Architects of AI' as its 2025 Person of the Year, OpenAI's release of GPT-5.2 for scientific problem-solving, a $52M funding round for 'Physical AI Scientists' developer Medra, Thales's new AI Security Fabric, and Zoovu's MCP Server for agentic commerce.

title: AI Digest — AI Giants Clash, Policy Tightens, and Pharma Gets a Boost

title: AI Digest — Infrastructure Collides with Code, Plus GPT-5.2's Expert Upgrade
name: Yi Qu
summary: This digest covers the release of OpenAI's GPT-5.2 with 'expert level' performance, the physical and financial limits of the AI infrastructure boom highlighted by Oracle's stock plunge, a new AI pact between Grace and Molecule.one to optimize peptide manufacturing, and the potential for AI to restart scientific progress and economic growth.
